info.headline: Flood Warning issued January 08 at 2:51PM EST until January 11 at 7:00AM EST by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...The National Weather Service in Greenville-Spartanburg SC has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in North Carolina... French Broad River At Blantyre affecting Henderson and Transylvania Counties. French Broad River Near Fletcher affecting Henderson and Buncombe Counties. .A potent storm system is expected to produce 4-6 inches of rainfall across the upper French Broad River watershed from early Tuesday morning through Tuesday evening. This rainfall will quickly overwhelm saturated soils and result in excessive runoff and significant stream rises across Transylvania and Henderson counties, with several tributaries of the French Broad River expected to exceed bankfull and cause flooding of adjacent areas as early as Tuesday morning. This excessive flow will cause the upper French Broad River from Rosman downstream to Brevard, Blantyre, Etowah, and Fletcher to exceed Minor Flood Stage late Tuesday morning into Tuesday afternoon and possibly Moderate Flood Stage by Wednesday morning. This will resulting in significant and damaging inundation within the river valley impacting farmland, numerous flood-prone roadways, and possibly some structures including outbuildings, barns, crawl spaces, and basements. Flooding may persist through early Thursday. Residents are advised to move vulnerable property to higher ground and stay up-to-date by monitoring the latest river levels and forecasts. ...FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT FROM TUESDAY AFTERNOON TO THURSDAY MORNING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...French Broad River near Fletcher. * WHEN...From Tuesday afternoon to Thursday morning. * IMPACTS...At 15.0 feet, Minor Flooding continues. French Broad River floodwaters may be impacting several roads within the valley, resulting in road closures including along Glenn Bridge Rd., Pinner Rd., Butler Bridge Rd., Nelson Rd., Banner Farm Rd., Brannon Rd., Old Brevard Hwy., and Ladson Rd. Widespread farmland flooding is ongoing with floodwaters impacting some residential and commercial property and outbuildings. Adjacent parks and river access points along the reach of the river are experiencing significant inundation. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1:30 PM EST Monday the stage was 5.4 feet and falling slowly. - Action/Advisory Stage is 10.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above Minor Flood Stage tomorrow afternoon and reach a crest of 15.0 feet early Wednesday morning. It will then fall below Minor Flood Stage by Wednesday afternoon. - Minor Flood Stage is 13.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 15.0 feet on 07/06/2013. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Even 6 inches of fast-moving flood water can knock you off your feet and a depth of 2 feet will float your car. Never try to walk, swim, or drive through such swift water. If you come upon flood waters, stop, turn around and go another way. Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. For detailed information including observed and forecast stages, flood impacts, flood history, FEMA Flood Hazard Layers, and more, please visit: https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=gsp The next statement will be issued before Wednesday afternoon at 145 PM EST.
